sect1.title: What References Are
sect1.simpara: References in PHP are means to call same variable content with different names. They are not like C pointers, they are symbol table aliases. Note that in PHP, variable names and variable content are different, so same content can have different names. The most close analogy is Unix filenames and files - variable names are directory entries, while variable contents is the file itself. References can be thought of as hardlinking in Unix filesystem.

sect1.title: What References Do
sect1.para:
PHP references allow you to make two variables to refer to the same content. Meaning, when you do:
$a =& $b
it means that $a and $b point to the same variable.
$a and $b are completely equal here, that's not $a is pointing to $b or vice versa, that's $a and $b pointing to the same place.
sect1.simpara: The third thing reference can do is return by-reference.

sect1.title: What References Are Not
sect1.simpara: What will happen that $var in foo will be bound with $bar in caller, but then it will be re-bound with $GLOBALS["baz"]. There's no way to bind $bar in the caller to something else using reference mechanism, since $bar is not available in the function foo (it is represented by $var, but $var has only variable contents and not name-to-value binding in the calling symbol table).

sect1.title: Returning References

note.simpara: Unlike parameter passing, here you have to use & in both places - to indicate that you return by-reference, not a copy as usual, and to indicate that reference binding, rather than usual assignment, should be done for $foo.

sect1.title: Unsetting References
sect1.simpara: Again, it might be useful to think about this as analogous to Unix unlink call.

sect1.title: Spotting References
sect1.simpara: Many syntax constructs in PHP are implemented via referencing mechanisms, so everything told above about reference binding also apply to these constructs. Some constructs, like passing and returning by-reference, are mentioned above. Other constructs that use references are:

sect2.title: global References
sect2.para:
When you declare variable as global $var you are in fact creating reference to a global variable. That means, this is the same as:
$var =& $GLOBALS["var"];
sect2.simpara: That means, for example, that unsetting $var won't unset global variable.
In an object method, $this is always reference to the caller object.
